creator: apacheBugzilla@AMammenT.cotse.net
text:
When I attempt to start batik-squiggle on my computer, I find that the startup 
process fails, with the report that there are insufficient file permissions.  

I have deployed the batik binary distributions to:
  D:\Program Files\JTools\batik-1.5

When running, after changing the the above directory and invoking:
  java -jar batik-squiggle.jar
the error message states that insufficient file permissions prevent the 
opening of \D:\Program Files\JTolls\batik-1.5\batik-squiggle.jar.  This seemed 
quite strange to me, so after some followup, it became clear that the problem 
was the extended windows file name (probably the space in "Program Files").  
Moving the directory to D:\batik-1.5 solved the problem temporarily, with the 
cost of constraining deployment to only paths with single word path elements.

creator: deweese@apache.org
text:
Hi,

   This works just fine for me on my system in the following tree:

     D:\Name With A Space\batik-1.5

   Perhaps the problem was with the program you unpacked the distribution
with (the install page suggests using jar instead of zip to unpack
because zip gets the permissions wrong in some cases).

   Anyway why is this filed with Batik?  What could we do to fix this
problem?

creator: apacheBugzilla@AMammenT.cotse.net
text:
I'll check it again with the same directory structure that you used.  
I'll also use jar to unpack the distribution.

This was filed with batik because squiggle is part of the batik distribution, 
and it doesn't appear to start properly.  Given that squiggle is a part of the 
distribution, and it didn't appear to start properly, I assumed one would 
consider it a bug.  (I didn't see any documentation which suggested that batik 
is not meant to run properly on Windows.)  

As a user, not a developer, it's a little difficult for me to describe exactly 
what you could do to fix the problem.  At least when I've been faced with bugs 
for projects on which I'm a developer, the following approach has worked 
decently:

1) Attempt to reproduce the problem - you've done this.
2) Examine the code to see if the problem is due to something in my code base, 
or in a library on which my code base depends.  
3a) Prioritize and fix the problem if it can be resolved in my code base.
3b) Submit a bug with the owners of the library, and investigate workarounds 
if the problem is due to something in a library.  
4) Record the findings of my investigation, and the approach to resolution 
selected as part of the original bug report.  

Does this answer your question?  On re-reading, my response seems flippant, 
but I'm not quite sure how else to answer....  I'd appreciate any 
clarification you could provide if this response was not what you were looking 
for....

Of course, in this case, the first step was sufficient.  I'll try to provide a 
prompt update - perhaps it's the JVM that's the problem - still something 
worth noting in the usage docs.  I was using Sun JDK 1.4.1_02 - were you using 
this as well?
